msContents.summary: Endowment of 20 kaḻañcus of gold. Out of the 3 kaḻañcus of yearly interest from this gold, 2 are endowed for the recitation of the tiruppatiyam beginning with the phrase kōlanaṟkuḻal, in Śrī-Govindapāṭi. The tiruppatiyam appears to have been composed by Muvēntappiṭavūr alias Kāyavāṉ Arunilai, the donor’s father.

div.p: Prosperity! Fortune!
In the tenth year of the king Rājarāja-kesasari-panma, who broke the vessel at the batlle of Kāntaḷūr-cālai...
This is the handwriting of the villagers from Vēḷkaḷa-veṇpākkam, next to holy Govintapāṭi in Tāmar-nāṭu.The account regarding Piṭavūr-nāṭu, on the northern border of Cōḻa-nāṭu, is the following:

This year, the received gift was this 20 marked tuḷai gold coins because of the endowment order for this quality gold under our responsability, fixed by kaiyāl Arunilai Śrīkṛṣṇaṉ, alias Muvēnta Piṭavūr, owner .
Three kaḻañcus of gold came each year through interest, being that one came through yearly interest, the second through monthly interest and the first of them came in the month of Puraṭṭāti.

Let the trustees–in charge of the temple śrīkāryam ceykiṉṟa of the Lord which will every year as long as the sun and the moon last–be appointed as collectors taṇṭi of the interest of three kaḻañcus of gold so that one kaḻañcu is for the heads of the temple kōyil nampimār to which they dedicated the holy hymn kēṭppitta and two kaḻañcus for the leaders of the assembly paridai nāyakaṉmār, who performed āṭiṉa–on the seventh day of the holy festival–the holy hymn tiruppatiyam that begins with kōlanaṟkuḻal, composedviṇṇapam ceyta by the devotee āḻvāṉ of holy Govintapāṭi, Kāyāvāṉ Arunilai, alias Muvēnta Piṭavūr Vēḷār, donor appaṉār of this gold.
If we appoint them, let them be the chosen for receiving the tax, needed for You, the temple managers that, by royal order, keep them hidden.
May we become the designated duty bearers kaṭavōm of this allowance nivantam that covers the tax taṇṇtam imposed by them.

We, the villagers of Vēḷkaḷa-Veṇpākkam, gave to Muvēnta Piṭavūr Vēḷār this endowment after agreeing in this way. I, master of Āṟaiyaṉ of holy Govintapāṭi, am the one who has handwritten in the stone, as indicated by the villagers.

This is for the protection of the holy vaiṣṇavas.
